content:
TUNICATES
l959 
A comprehensive survey of developmental processes in the
tunicates would include examination not only of eggs and embryos
but also of metamorphosing larvae, various types of vegetative re-
production, and vegenerating forms. Because these developmental
forms must be constantly related to the structure of larvae and
adults, it is necessary that the student should first of all re-
view in a standard text the anatomy and life history of the common
types of tunicates,
A. SIMPLE ASCIDIANS
DEVELUPMENT T0 THE TADFOLE STAGE.
Styela. (Old name 
Since the publication of Conklin's description of the develop~
ment of Styela eggs (l905), these have been a classic example of
the determination of embryonic organs and tissues in the?undivided
egg following fertilization. With certain concessions to recent
experiments, Styela is still one of the best cases of "mosaic
development". Refer to Conklin's figures while observing the

a) Methods.
Though truly hermaphroditic, Styela is ordinarily self-sterile
like several other ascidians. It sheds its eggs and sperm early
in the evening, and fertilization takes place when gametes from
different individuals get mixed in the same region er dish. It is
easy to have eggs shed and fertilized on normal schedule in the
laboratory, but it is a great disadvantage to have to study the
migrations of yellow pigment within them by artificial light.
Therefor, it has been customary to open a number of large
individuals, remove theiigbright orange gonads and mince these up
together in a dish, afterward filling the dish with sea water,
stirring, and.removing the coarse debris from the center with a
pipette. Eggs, oocytes, oogonia and all developmental stages of
sperm are left floating in the water. Whatever time the eggs present will be capable of fertilization, and
will begin development within the next few minutes. 
Recently, S. N. Rose has found that shedding of normal ripe
eggs and spermf can be induced at any time of day by controlling
light. His method is to select a number of large healthy individ-
uals and to put them under a strong electric light watt
bulb) in a dish of running sea water, the action of the light
apparently inhibiting maturatien and shedding. Them, depending
on when material is needed, the animals are put in the dark. At
any time after early evening they respond to this by shedding
their gametes within an hour or so.
Fnrtilized eggs may then be collected from,a dish.that has
contained several individuals, or ripe eggs and sperm from a dish
dontaining a single individual. Timed fertilization can be accom~
plished simply by mixing the gametes from two isolated individuals,
